utterances: Nice to be with you.
So, Ron, if this bill clears the Senate, how effective really will it be?

Well, I have to tell you, as a free market fiscal conservative, I'm always nervous when the government tries to step in and take the assumption of the rest or to take the responsibility of the risk of obtaining a mortgage.
I do believe that the Congress will act and I do believe a bill will be sent to the president for signature this year.

The question will be, how much responsibilities that Congress wish to assume for people who should have taken more precaution and people who should have, unfortunately, paid more attention before they took these loans out that are skyrocketing and forcing them out of their homes?
But, Ron, there are always limits that are imposed by various governments for various reasons.
Some people have said that these businesses essentially pushed these loans to consumers in ways where consumers didn't understand.
Maybe it was a question of language.
What do you think of that?
I agree with that.
And I am very concerned when you look at red lining that is skyrocketing insurance premiums based on a particular demographic in a particular area.
And I think that there is a strong oversight responsibility that Congress must exercise to ensure that predatory lending did not take place.
And if it did take place, then I think the punitive actions will come into place.
But again, as a free market fiscal conservative, I'm just very, very cautious and very nervous about the federal government making people's assumption of the risk.
So, Mary, this bill passed by the House allows for greater relief in the limits proposed by the Bush administration.
So why might the Bush administration be more conservative with this issue?
Well, they would be more conservative for the same reason that Ron objects to the bill on free market conservative grounds.
Although, when it's to their benefit, politically, to have the government take action, they go ahead and take action.

Also, in a week, when the Federal Reserve board has just cut interest rates when it previously opened its loan window to banks at lower rates and urged them to come to take loans, when it is essentially bailing out the banking industry and the hedge funders and all the people who financed mergers and acquisitions and all the big guys up the top.
It seems to me to be wrong to say that somebody shouldn't help the little guy down at the bottom who has made these loans.
And in fact, the people who didn't understand and who were pushed into it and who took the greatest risk and who now are in the worst trouble need help more than anybody.
So that - what the Congress has done - and you will know that lots of Republicans voted for the House bill, it simply wasn't Democrats.
I mean, Republicans voted overwhelmingly.
There are enough votes there to overwrite a veto.
It just seems that, in fairness, we ought to do something for the little people and keep the economy going.

When the economy is bad and you're headed toward what looks like a recession, you can either take the Andrew Mellon at the time of the depression position and say: Liquidate, liquidate, let's ring out all the excess.
Let everybody suffer or you can try to help everybody.
This is to help the little guy.
And I think that even if Bush vetoes it, Congress will pass over his veto.
Well, Mary, the one thing I'd say though, I agree, obviously, with what the administration has done because I think that there is room to modernize the FHA program.
I think there is a strong momentum that all of us would agree that you should be able to expand the amount of money that people who can qualify for these loans and to have certain forgiveness.

But I just worry about the federal government making an assumption that we should come in and bail people out on these particular loans because I don't want the United States government involved in a regulation or at least ownership of the mortgage industry anymore as it turns to health care, which I know Farai will talk about in a minute - that the federal government should be providing universal one-size-fits-all health care.
So I am all for those who are at the lower end of the strata who are most adversely impacted by this.
I just don't want to believe that the federal government has that proper role(ph) to be interceding there.
And probably in favor of the banks also getting bailed out.
And also…
No. No.
…the big hedge funds getting bailed out too.
David Leavitt, author of ""The Man Who Knew Too Much: Alan Turing and the Origins of Computer.
I shun but we sell a lot of that, too.
It went black.
A lot of people - I wrote today that a lot of people across the country probably thought their cable or their satellite went out.
Uh-mm.
And, of course, the most terrible moment it could possibly go out.
Right.
And we're left then to do what television so rarely ask us to do, which is to think.
Exactly.
And I think that a lot of people are - Neal, they're having a hard time getting their heads around that because, you know, broadcast television doesn't really want you to do that.
Everything gets tied up in a bow.
Every ending is perfectly explained, sometimes, two or three times, in case you didn't get it the first time.
But ""The Sopranos"" have never been about - like that.
David Chase has never wanted this show to be something - he's called one - like little movies in these hours.
And he's never delivered anything to us that's really pat.
And I never expected him to go out that way.
That's why, I thought that this finale was perfect because, you know, I kind of had always hoped that we would have this glimpse of ""The Sopranos"" and then the camera would just go off.
Like we just, you know, life goes on for Tony and we'll just never know.
Now, there's an interpretation out there, that when it went to black, the guy came back out of the bathroom and killed him from behind.
I don't actually buy into that.
I think it's a credible theory.
I don't think it's an off-the-wall theory.
There's a lot of off-the-wall theories, Neal.
But I don't think that one is too wild, but I just don't believe it.

I think what happened was, I think, in the episode, Chase clearly sets up that a member of Tony's crew has flipped, that the feds are going to press - are ready, some of the subpoenas are going to out.
They're going to press for indictments.
It's looking more likely for an indictment even that, it usually looks.
Exactly.
Right.
And you know, and throughout the series, Chase has basically had let Tony say, there's two ways you end up.
Eighty percent of the time, you end up in jail and then you end up on a slab.
But I think what he's hinting at in this, is that Tony's probably going to end up, somehow, facing a court battle.
Whether he wins or loses, we don't know.
But I don't think he envisioned him dying.
I think he said look, this is a slice of life, and to Tony, life goes on.
End of series.
Let's see if we can get some listeners involved in this conversation.
Again, 800-989-8255, email - talk@npr.org.
Our guest, Tim Goodman, the TV critic for the San Francisco Chronicle.
And let's start with Tim(ph).
And Tim's calling us from Georgia.
Hi.
How are you doing?
All right.
I thought the series was - the series now is - was a great way to end the series.

Now I think it was interesting what Mr. Goodman said about Tony's life going on because something we haven't seen discussed in a lot of the blogs is how the characters persists even after they're dead.
Like Chris' character threw the cat, you know.
Uncle Junior, even though he's in a mental institution, he still has his way in the series.
His influence is still felt even though he is not a part of the plot anymore.
And I thought that was a really interesting way to end in the real - subtle way to go out, a very subtle (unintelligible) play at the end.
I wanted to ask Tim Goodman about that.
Also, there is the cat.
And again, for those who haven't seen it, the cat keeps looking at Christopher's picture no matter where they move the picture.
I thought the cat had the bug in it for a while.
But anyway, that was just another red herring for me.
But there's that very moving scene with Uncle Junior, the man who was, of course, with Tony's father…
(Unintelligible)
…ran North Jersey and then eventually in a fit of - in a mental fit, ended up last year shooting Tony Soprano.
Yeah.
I think that there was a lot of herrings and also a lot of great moments like that.
And what people forget is that in an hour and five minutes, David Chase was sort of charged with wrapping up seven years of very difficult storylines, but he was never going to wrap all of them up.
I think he wanted to give some closure to some storylines to give you the sense that life is going to go on.
But he was never going, you know, the Russian was never going to come back out of the woods.
But yeah, it was great.
I thought there was a lot of moments in the series where your Adrenalin was coming up, but it was just another herring.
It was just - that's part of the given take, the cat and mouse that Chase plays in this series.
And, you know, part of me, I think, this was kind of harsh to say to people who are fans of this series they might be upset.
But I think a lot of people have watched ""The Sopranos"" over the years and have perceived it to be something that David Chase didn't want it to be.
I don't think he ever envisioned it as a, you know, a whack-a-week kind of mobster drama, it was much deeper than that.
And it was never something that -it was going to be a really pat-safe(ph) ending that made you feel good.
And when they didn't get it, I think that is his way of saying, you know, maybe you just didn't get it from the start.
But there was also that part where he's talking to Uncle Junior, who's got Alzheimer's disease…
Right.
…and can't remember, and the tragedy that, you know, Tony seems to be coming up on is he - his father will not be remembered, Uncle Junior will not be remembered, he will not be remembered.
Exactly.
There was a lot of that about - a lot of stuff about the past and how things go forward and how messed up they are in comparison to the older ways.
Anyway, Tim, thanks for the call.
Thank you very much.
Have a good day.
You too.
Let's see if we can get Lisa(ph) on the line.
Lisa's with us from Boulder, Colorado.
Hi there.
Hi.

I thought that the ending was just great and I also think - I'm one of the people to think that what happened was that Tony got whacked because if you think of the foreshadowing that happened earlier, like, last week, I believe that there was a - right before Bobby got shot, there was him remembering that he and Tony had sat in the boat.
And he said, well, and then you never, I bet you don't even hear anything is what Bobby said.
And he kind of laughed.
And then if you noticed, the soundtrack went dead quiet not just was the blackening of the screen, but continued through the entire credits that it was quiet, there was no noise.
